source.raw_text:
The Trap-Bar Row is a compound back exercise targeting the lats, rhomboids, traps (mid-back) for thickness and width, while also engaging rear delts, biceps, forearms, and the core for stability, making it great for overall upper back strength and grip. The movement pattern is a hip hinge with powerful elbow drive, focusing on pulling the bar towards the belly button while maintaining a flat back, challenging the posterior chain (glutes/hamstrings) isometrically. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
This video demonstrates the muscle engagement during the trap bar row: 
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Back): Latissimus Dorsi (lats), Rhomboids, Trapezius (mid/lower). 
• Secondary Movers (Pulling/Stabilizers): Rear Deltoids, Biceps, Forearms, Erector Spinae (lower back), Glutes/Hamstrings (isometric hold), Core (obliques, abs). [2, 3, 4]  

You can see a visual breakdown of the muscles worked in this video: 
Movement Pattern 

1. Setup: Stand inside the trap bar with feet hip-width apart, knees soft, hinging at the hips with a flat back (like a deadlift start). 
2. Grip: Grab the handles with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). 
3. Pull (Concentric): Drive your elbows back, squeezing your shoulder blades together as you pull the bar towards your midsection. 
4. Hold: Briefly squeeze your back muscles at the top. 
5. Lower (Eccentric): Control the weight back down, extending your hips and maintaining a flat back, inhaling as you lower. [1, 3, 5, 6, 7]  

This video shows the step-by-step technique for performing the trap bar row: 
Key Technique Points 

• Flat Back: Essential to protect your lower back and effectively target the upper back. 
• Elbow Drive: Focus on pulling your elbows back, not just your hands. 
• Glute/Hamstring Engagement: Keep your posterior chain tight to support your torso. 
• Core Bracing: Engage your core to maintain spinal stability. [1, 4]
